facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2322 of 1968 was heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2322 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the order dated

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court order dated October 4, 1968 in Special Civil Application No. 2053 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated October 4, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applic

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed in limine application under Articles 226 and 227 to quash judgment of Assistant Judge at Sangli in Election Petition No. 10 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mitter, J. This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the B

facts.text: Election of councillors to Sangli City Municipality held on June 3, 1967 under Maharashtra Municipalities Act, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are as follows. On June 3, 1967 election of companyncillors to the Sangli City Municipality was held

facts.text: Counting of votes for Ward No. 25 took place on June 4, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: under the Maharashtra Municipalities Act, 1965  hereinafter referred to as the Act. The companynting of votes

facts.text: Election results published in Official Gazette on June 15, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: took place with regard to Ward No. 25 on June 4, 1967. According to the election petition, the results were pu

facts.text: Election petition filed on June 24, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: blished in the Official Gazette on June 15, 1967 and the petition was filed on June 24, 1967. The petitioner

facts.text: Petitioner was a candidate from Ward No. 25 and challenged appellant's election on grounds including publication of undated defamatory pamphlet arousing religious sentiments.

anchor.surface_text: who was himself a candidate for election from the said ward challenged the election of the appellant before us on several grounds set forth in paragraph 3 of the petition. The first of these was to the effect that the appellant bad, with the help of his supporters, published an undated pamphlet and circulated the same on a large scale among the voters in Ward No. 25 and that the said pamphlet companytained untrue, false and defamatory statements about the petitioner thereby prejudicing the voters generally against him and in particular instigating the Muslim voters to vote against him by arousing their religious sentiments.

facts.text: Another ground: defamatory pamphlet dated May 30, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Another similar ground based on a defamatory pamphlet dated 30th May 1967 was urged in the petition. Charges of terrorising voters and securing votes by false personation were also levelled therein.

facts.text: Appellant denied responsibility for publication of impugned pamphlets.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant however repelled the charges mentioned above and denied that he was responsible for the publication of any of the impugned pamphlets.

facts.text: First issue: whether petitioner proved opponent No. 1 used malpractices by arousing religious sentiments and defamatory statements via pamphlets.

anchor.surface_text: Of the four issues framed at the hearing of the petition, the first was whether the petitioner proved that opponent No. 1 who was elected as Municipal Councillor for Ward No. 25 had used malpractices at the time at the election by arousing religious sentiments of the voters and making defamatory statements against the petitioner by publishing pamphlets?

facts.text: On August 21, 1968, petitioner applied for summons for witnesses Hakim Abdul Rahiman Shaikh and Gopal Chintaman Ghugare; rejected by Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On August 21, 1968 the petitioner made an application before the Judge for issuing summons on these two persons as his witnesses, but the learned Judge rejected that application.

facts.text: Appellant's case closed on August 21, 1968; arguments started August 22, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was closed on the same day and the arguments started on August 22, 1968.

facts.text: On August 22, 1968, court adjourned to August 24, 1968 to record evidence of two witnesses as court witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: On that date the companyrt adjourned the hearing of the case to August 24, 1968 for recording the evidence of these two witnesses in respect of whom an application had been made by the election petitioner on the previous day.

facts.text: Two witnesses examined on August 24, 1968 as court witnesses; arguments concluded thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: These two persons were examined on the 24th August as companyrt witnesses and thereafter the argument of companynsel was resumed and companycluded.

facts.text: Assistant Judge delivered judgment on August 30, 1968 allowing election petition on first issue.

anchor.surface_text: By judgment delivered on August 30, 1968 the learned Judge allowed the election petition holding in favour of the petitioner on the first issue.

facts.text: Appellant disqualified from municipal elections for five years.

anchor.surface_text: and made an order disqualifying him under the Act from taking part in municipal elections for the next.five years.

facts.text: Trial court found appellant guilty of publishing and distributing first undated pamphlet.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Judge accepted his testimony and came to the companyclusion that the appellant had been personally responsible for the distribution of the first pamphlet and as such found him guilty of a companyrupt practice

facts.text: Hakim Abdul Rahiman Shaikh testified he received pamphlet on June 2, 1967 from appellant at mosque.

anchor.surface_text: The other witness Hakim Abdul Rahiman Shaikh stated categorically that he had received a companyy of the pamphlet on the day previous to the municipal election, that is to say, on June 2, 1967 and he gave full particulars as to how he came to receive it. He stated that he had attended a prayer meeting at a mosque on the 2nd June and after the Namaj was over the appellant had read over the pamphlet

facts.text: Pamphlet contained defamatory statements about petitioner K. Kadlaskar, accusing him of ostracism from Muslim community, mismanagement of Kabarasthan, conviction, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The pamphlet read K. Kadlaskar, who companytests the election from Ward No. 25 is an independent candidate, has been ostracized from the Muslim companymunity and he has numbersupport of the Muslim companymunity and therefore numberody should vote for him. While Kadlaskar was in charge of the management of the Kabarasthan, he was extracting Rs. 12 for allowing the members of Muslim companymunity to bury their dead and had prohibited the burial of the dead bodies of dancing girls and had extracted hundreds of rupees from the persons whose dead were buried there. He turned the Kabarasthan into a brothel and was trading in illicit liquor for which he was companyvicted. Recently he got published a pamphlet in the name of his mistress Noorjahan Bapulal Kavathekar to defame Mohamad Umar Shaikh and he is making some imputations against the private character of Mohmad Umar and Moulana Innan and numberody should vote for this mean-minded and anti- social person.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, therefore, the appeal fails but in the circumstances of this case, we make numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: There was a Gazette publication on June 8, 1967 and another on June 15, 1967 declaring election results.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the second point, the learned companynsel argued by reference to two publications in the Maharashtra Gazette, the one of June 8, 1967 and the other of June 15, 1967

facts.text: Appellant accepted statements in paragraphs 1 and 2 of the petition regarding declaration of results and cause of action.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant precluded himself from doing so by his unconditional acceptance of the statements in paragrapbs 1 and 2 of the petition.

issues.text: Whether the procedure adopted by the trial court was wrong in examining as court witnesses two persons previously cited by the petitioner after initially refusing to issue summonses to them

anchor.surface_text: The first point was that the procedure adopted by the trial court was wrong in that the two witnesses who were examined as court witnesses had been cited by the election petitioner earlier and the learned Judge had in the exercise of jurisdiction vested in him refused to issue summonses to them when he was asked to do so on August 21, 1968.

issues.text: Whether the election petition was filed beyond the period prescribed by the Act and was not maintainable

anchor.surface_text: The second point was that the election petition was filed beyond the period prescribed by the Act and as such it was not maintainable.

issues.text: Whether the first issue framed by the trial court was so confusing and misleading that there was no fair trial to the prejudice of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The third point was that the first issue which was decided against the appellant was so confusing and misleading that there was no fair trial of the petition to the prejudice of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether there was no evidence of corrupt practice of which the appellant could be found guilty

anchor.surface_text: The fourth point was that in any event there was no evidence of corrupt practice of which the appellant could be found guilty.

issues.text: Whether the order disqualifying the appellant for five years was unduly harsh and ought to be set aside

anchor.surface_text: The fifth point was that the order of the Judge disqualifying the appellant for a period of five years was unduly harsh and ought to be set aside.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner proved that opponent No. 1 used malpractices at the election by arousing religious sentiments of the voters and making defamatory statements against the petitioner by publishing pamphlets

anchor.surface_text: There was no error apparent on the face of the record before the High Court and consequently the jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution could not have been exercised on the facts of the case by the issue of a writ of certiorari. arguments.qualifiers: There can be no two opinions about

holdings.text: The learned Judge had jurisdiction to call the two persons as court witnesses under s.21(7) of the Maharashtra Municipalities Act, 1965, which confers wider powers than O.XVI r.14 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that under this section, the Judge is given powers wider than those given by the Code of Civil Procedure under 0. 16 r. 14 inasmuch as the section does not prescribe any prerequisite to the examination of a person as court witness as envisaged by the Code of Civil Procedure. In our view, the learned Judge had jurisdiction to call these two persons as witnesses under the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.21(7) explicitly allows suo motu summoning without prerequisites unlike CPC; applies directly to facts.

holdings.text: Even under Representation of the People Act, 1951 without similar provision, courts have wide power to summon witnesses in corrupt practice cases.

anchor.surface_text: We may note that even under the Representation of the People Act, 1951 which does not contain a similar provision it has been held by this Court that although the trial court should be at arms length...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in M. Seshadri v. G. Vasanta Pai emphasizing wide amplitude for investigating corrupt practices.

holdings.text: No prejudice caused to appellant by procedure; opportunity to rebut not denied; first point fails.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant would have had a real cause for grievance if he had asked for an opportunity to rebut the evidence of these two witnesses and had been denied the same but this has nowhere been alleged. On the evidence no exception can be taken...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant did not seek rebuttal; evidence sufficient; no violation of natural justice.

holdings.text: Election petition not time-barred; appellant precluded by unconditional acceptance of paras 1 and 2 of petition stating publication on June 15.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant precluded himself from doing so by his unconditional acceptance of the statements in paragraphs 1 and 2 of the petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission in written statement waives limitation challenge under s.21(1); no error apparent on record.

holdings.text: No error apparent on record warranting certiorari under Art.226 or superintendence under Art.227.

anchor.surface_text: There was no error apparent on the face of the record before the High Court and consequently the jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution could not have been exercised... Neither could the High Court have set aside the order of the trial court under Art. 227

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's jurisdiction limited; no transgression of Act's limits; writ not for re-appreciation of evidence.

holdings.text: Framing of first issue unsatisfactory but did not vitiate trial; appellant aware of points to meet.

anchor.surface_text: There is certainly some substance in the grievance... but we cannot come to the conclusion that because of the unsatisfactory nature of the issues framed, the whole trial is vitiated. The appellant knew exactly what points he had to meet.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prejudice shown; evidence adduced on issues; fair trial ensured.

holdings.text: Sufficient evidence of corrupt practice; no ground to interfere with trial judge's acceptance of witness testimony.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged... that there was enough material... but this does not mean that everything deposed to by him should be rejected and when the trial Judge accepted the evidence... we see no reason to interfere...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not for writ jurisdiction to re-appraise evidence; trial judge's finding on credibility upheld.

holdings.text: Distribution of pamphlet constitutes corrupt practice of arousing religious sentiments and defamation.

anchor.surface_text: If the distribution of the pamphlet be accepted, there can be no doubt that the appellant was guilty of trying to arouse religious sentiments of the voters... The pamphlet starts off by describing the election petitioner as a person ostracised from the Muslim community.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contents defamatory and incite communal feelings; applies corrupt practice provisions of Act.

holdings.text: Five-year disqualification appropriate and not unduly harsh.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the last point, it was for the learned Judge to have come to his own conclusion as to the period of disqualification. The maximum penalty... was disqualification for six years and we see no reason to take any exception...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Within statutory maximum; proportionate to serious corrupt practice.

holdings.text: Appeal fails; no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that under this section, the Judge is given powers wider than those given by the Code of Civil Procedure under 0. 16 r. 14 inasmuch as the section does not prescribe any prerequisite to the examination of a person as court witness as envisaged by the Code of Civil Procedure. In our view, the learned Judge had jurisdiction to call these two persons as witnesses under the provisions of the Act.
In the result, therefore, the appeal fails but in the circumstances of this case, we make no order as to costs.
